categories.name: Metaphysics
categories.description: Fundamental questions about reality, existence, and being

categories.name: Epistemology
categories.description: Nature of knowledge, belief, and justified truth

categories.name: Ethics
categories.description: Moral principles, values, and right vs wrong

categories.name: Logic
categories.description: Principles of valid reasoning and inference

categories.name: Political Philosophy
categories.description: Government, justice, rights, and social organization

categories.name: Philosophy of Mind
categories.description: Nature of consciousness, mind, and mental states

axioms.title: Something exists
axioms.description: At minimum, my thoughts, experiences, or some form of existence is occurring right now.

axioms.title: Basic logic is reliable
axioms.description: Contradictions indicate error. If something is true, its opposite cannot also be true in the same way.

axioms.title: Patterns and regularities exist
axioms.description: Some things happen more predictably than others. There are observable regularities in experience.

axioms.title: Some differences matter more than others
axioms.description: Not all states, outcomes, or experiences are equivalent. Some distinctions have significance.

axioms.title: Reasoning can discover truth
axioms.description: Careful thinking and analysis can sometimes lead to more accurate conclusions than random guessing.

axioms.title: Actions have consequences
axioms.description: What we do affects what happens next. Choices and behaviors lead to different outcomes.

axioms.title: Suffering exists
axioms.description: Pain, distress, and unwanted experiences are real phenomena that occur.

axioms.title: Communication between minds is possible
axioms.description: Ideas, meanings, and information can be shared between different thinking beings.

axioms.title: Choices can be made
axioms.description: There are situations where different options are available and selection between them is possible.

axioms.title: Cooperation is possible
axioms.description: Different agents can work together toward shared goals and mutual benefit.

axioms.title: Reasoning in Ethics is valid
axioms.description: Logical reasoning and inference can produce valid conclusions in the domain of ethics

axioms.title: Ethics domain is valid
axioms.description: Moral reasoning can distinguish between right and wrong actions

axioms.title: Reasoning in Consciousness is valid
axioms.description: Logical reasoning and inference can produce valid conclusions in the domain of consciousness

axioms.title: Consciousness domain is valid
axioms.description: Consciousness and mental phenomena are valid subjects of investigation

axioms.title: Reasoning in Political is valid
axioms.description: Logical reasoning and inference can produce valid conclusions in the domain of political

axioms.title: Political domain is valid
axioms.description: Political and social arrangements can be evaluated and improved

arguments.title: Objective reality exists
arguments.description: If something exists and logic works, then there must be an objective reality that exists independently of any particular mind's beliefs about it.
arguments.conclusion: Reality is objective and mind-independent

arguments.title: Knowledge is possible
arguments.description: If patterns exist and reasoning can discover truth, then it's possible to gain genuine knowledge about reality through observation and thinking.
arguments.conclusion: Humans can acquire reliable knowledge about the world

arguments.title: Moral facts exist
arguments.description: If differences matter and suffering exists, then it matters whether suffering occurs or not, creating objective moral facts.
arguments.conclusion: Some actions are objectively better or worse than others

arguments.title: Moral responsibility exists
arguments.description: If actions have consequences and choices can be made, then agents can be held responsible for the outcomes of their freely chosen actions.
arguments.conclusion: People are morally responsible for their choices

arguments.title: Rational discourse is possible
arguments.description: If communication between minds is possible and reasoning can discover truth, then people can share ideas and potentially reach agreement through rational discussion.
arguments.conclusion: Meaningful dialogue and persuasion are possible

arguments.title: Social cooperation and agreements are possible
arguments.description: If cooperation is possible and actions have consequences, then people can form mutually beneficial agreements and social structures.
arguments.conclusion: Society and governance can be legitimately organized

arguments.title: Causal laws govern reality
arguments.description: If patterns exist and actions have consequences, then reality operates according to discoverable causal laws and regularities.
arguments.conclusion: The universe operates according to natural laws

arguments.title: Reality has stable structure
arguments.description: If something exists and patterns exist, then reality has some stable, persistent structure that enables consistent patterns.
arguments.conclusion: The world has an underlying stable structure

arguments.title: Values can guide rational choice
arguments.description: If choices can be made and differences matter, then rational agents can use values and preferences to guide their decision-making.
arguments.conclusion: Rational value-based decision making is possible

arguments.title: Preventing unnecessary harm matters
arguments.description: If suffering exists and actions have consequences, then actions that prevent or reduce unnecessary suffering have moral significance.
arguments.conclusion: We have moral reasons to prevent unnecessary suffering

arguments.title: Shared standards of reasoning are possible
arguments.description: If logic is reliable and communication between minds is possible, then people can share and apply common standards of reasoning.
arguments.conclusion: Universal logical principles can guide human thought

arguments.title: Justice and fairness are achievable
arguments.description: If cooperation is possible and moral facts exist, then people can work together to create just institutions based on objective moral principles.
arguments.conclusion: Just societies can be established and maintained

arguments.title: Scientific method discovers objective truths
arguments.description: If knowledge is possible and objective reality exists, then systematic empirical investigation can discover objective truths about the natural world.
arguments.conclusion: Science provides reliable knowledge about reality

arguments.title: Moral progress is possible
arguments.description: If moral facts exist and rational discourse is possible, then humanity can make genuine progress in understanding and implementing moral truths.
arguments.conclusion: Moral knowledge and practice can improve over time

arguments.title: Prediction and control of nature is possible
arguments.description: If causal laws govern reality and knowledge is possible, then we can predict future events and control natural processes through understanding.
arguments.conclusion: Technology and engineering are fundamentally sound enterprises

arguments.title: Legitimate government is possible
arguments.description: If justice is achievable and social cooperation is possible, then legitimate political authority can be established through just institutions.
arguments.conclusion: Good governance based on consent and justice is achievable

arguments.title: We have ethical obligations to others
arguments.description: If moral responsibility exists and preventing harm matters, then we have genuine obligations to consider the welfare of other moral agents.
arguments.conclusion: Ethics involves duties to others, not just personal preferences

arguments.title: Metaphysical realism is true
arguments.description: If objective reality exists and reality has stable structure, then there exists a mind-independent world with definite properties and structures.
arguments.conclusion: The world exists independently of human thought and has objective features

arguments.title: Objective values exist
arguments.description: If values can guide rational choice and moral facts exist, then there are objective values that provide genuine reasons for action.
arguments.conclusion: Some values are objectively better than others

arguments.title: Universal standards of rationality are possible
arguments.description: If shared reasoning standards are possible and knowledge is achievable, then universal principles of rational thought can be identified and applied.
arguments.conclusion: Reason provides universal criteria for evaluating beliefs and arguments

arguments.title: Philosophical inquiry has value
arguments.description: If rational discourse is possible and moral progress is achievable, then philosophical reflection and debate can contribute to human understanding and improvement.
arguments.conclusion: Philosophy can make genuine contributions to human knowledge and welfare

arguments.title: Natural kinds and essences exist
arguments.description: If reality has stable structure and causal laws exist, then nature is organized into real kinds with essential properties that ground causal powers.
arguments.conclusion: Scientific classification reflects objective features of reality

arguments.title: Rule of law is essential for justice
arguments.description: If legitimate government is possible and social cooperation requires agreements, then consistent application of just laws is necessary for social order.
arguments.conclusion: Legal institutions must operate according to impartial, consistent principles

arguments.title: Universal human rights exist
arguments.description: If we have ethical obligations to others and legitimate government is possible, then all humans possess fundamental rights that just governments must protect.
arguments.conclusion: Human rights provide universal moral and political standards

arguments.title: Naturalism is well-supported
arguments.description: If science discovers objective truths and metaphysical realism is true, then the naturalistic worldview that relies on scientific methods is strongly supported.
arguments.conclusion: The natural world as described by science is likely all that exists

arguments.title: The Enlightenment project is valid
arguments.description: If moral progress is possible and universal rationality exists, then the Enlightenment goal of using reason to improve human conditions is a valid and achievable project.
arguments.conclusion: Reason can guide humanity toward better societies and institutions

arguments.title: Technology must serve human dignity
arguments.description: If prediction and control of nature is possible and universal human rights exist, then technological development should be guided by respect for human dignity and rights.
arguments.conclusion: Technological progress must be ethically constrained

arguments.title: Constitutional democracy is optimal
arguments.description: If legitimate government is possible and rule of law is essential, then constitutional democracies that limit power through law provide the best form of government.
arguments.conclusion: Constitutional democratic systems best protect liberty and enable flourishing

arguments.title: Virtue ethics provides moral guidance
arguments.description: If we have ethical obligations to others and objective values exist, then cultivating virtuous character traits that align with objective values is morally important.
arguments.conclusion: Character development and virtue cultivation are central to ethics

arguments.title: Interdisciplinary inquiry enhances understanding
arguments.description: If philosophical inquiry has value and science discovers truths, then combining philosophical reflection with scientific investigation yields deeper understanding.
arguments.conclusion: Philosophy and science should collaborate to address fundamental questions

arguments.title: Scientific theories refer to real entities
arguments.description: If natural kinds exist and universal rationality is possible, then successful scientific theories genuinely refer to real structures and entities in nature.
arguments.conclusion: Theoretical entities postulated by science likely exist

arguments.title: Secular humanism is a viable worldview
arguments.description: If universal human rights exist and naturalism is well-supported, then a non-religious humanistic worldview can provide adequate moral and meaning frameworks.
arguments.conclusion: Religious belief is not necessary for moral living and human flourishing

arguments.title: Technology should be democratically governed
arguments.description: If constitutional democracy is optimal and technology must serve humanity, then democratic institutions should guide technological development and regulation.
arguments.conclusion: Citizens should have democratic input into technological choices affecting society

arguments.title: Practical wisdom should be cultivated
arguments.description: If virtue ethics provides moral guidance and interdisciplinary inquiry enhances understanding, then developing practical wisdom through broad learning is essential for good living.
arguments.conclusion: Education should aim at developing practical wisdom, not just technical skills

arguments.title: Artificial consciousness is theoretically possible
arguments.description: If naturalism is well-supported and prediction/control are possible, then consciousness could theoretically be replicated in artificial systems.
arguments.conclusion: Machines could potentially be conscious

arguments.title: Technological intervention in human nature is ethically permissible
arguments.description: If technology must serve humanity and moral progress is possible, then using technology to improve human capabilities can be ethically justified.
arguments.conclusion: Human enhancement through technology can be moral

arguments.title: Liberal democracy is the optimal political system
arguments.description: If constitutional democracy is optimal and human rights are universal, then liberal democratic systems best protect individual rights while enabling collective governance.
arguments.conclusion: Liberal democracy optimally balances individual freedom with collective coordination

arguments.title: Technological progress is generally beneficial
arguments.description: If prediction and control are possible and moral progress is achievable, then technological advancement generally improves human welfare when properly guided.
arguments.conclusion: Technology, when ethically guided, improves human conditions

arguments.title: Effective institutions are achievable
arguments.description: If legitimate government is possible and philosophical inquiry is valuable, then human societies can design and implement effective institutions through reasoned analysis.
arguments.conclusion: Good institutional design is possible through rational inquiry

arguments.title: Objective moral knowledge is possible
arguments.description: If objective values exist and universal rationality is possible, then humans can gain genuine knowledge about moral truths through rational inquiry.
arguments.conclusion: Moral truths can be discovered through reason

arguments.title: The mind-body problem is solvable
arguments.description: If naturalism is well-supported and scientific method is valid, then the relationship between consciousness and physical processes can eventually be scientifically understood.
arguments.conclusion: Science can eventually explain consciousness

arguments.title: Global cooperation is achievable
arguments.description: If effective institutions are achievable and enlightenment project is valid, then international cooperation on global challenges is possible through rational institution building.
arguments.conclusion: Humanity can cooperate effectively on global challenges

arguments.title: Technological singularity is conceptually possible
arguments.description: If scientific method is valid and prediction/control are possible, then rapid technological acceleration leading to superintelligence could theoretically occur.
arguments.conclusion: Accelerating technological progress could lead to transformative AI

arguments.title: Moral enhancement through technology is justified
arguments.description: If moral progress is possible and technological intervention is permissible, then using technology to improve human moral capacities is ethically justified.
arguments.conclusion: We should use technology to make humans more moral

arguments.title: Simulation hypothesis is plausible
arguments.description: If artificial consciousness is possible and computational power grows exponentially, then advanced civilizations likely run ancestor simulations.
arguments.conclusion: We might be living in a computer simulation

arguments.title: Death becomes optional through technology
arguments.description: If scientific method is valid and biological limitations are surmountable, then aging and death could become technologically preventable.
arguments.conclusion: Radical life extension or immortality may become achievable

arguments.title: Human nature is improvable through technology
arguments.description: If technological intervention is permissible and scientific method is valid, then human biological and psychological limitations can be technologically overcome.
arguments.conclusion: Humans can transcend natural limitations through technology

arguments.title: Technological unemployment becomes inevitable
arguments.description: If artificial consciousness is possible and technological progress is beneficial, then advanced AI will eventually automate most human jobs.
arguments.conclusion: Most current jobs will be automated by advanced AI

arguments.title: Economic systems can be reformed
arguments.description: If effective institutions are achievable and global cooperation is possible, then economic systems can be reformed to address technological disruption.
arguments.conclusion: Economic institutions can adapt to technological change

arguments.title: Consequentialist ethics is fundamentally correct
arguments.description: If objective moral knowledge is possible and suffering matters morally, then moral rightness depends primarily on outcomes and consequences.
arguments.conclusion: Actions should be judged primarily by their consequences

arguments.title: Future generations have moral worth
arguments.description: If universal human rights exist and consequentialist ethics is correct, then future people have equal moral standing to present people.
arguments.conclusion: We have moral obligations to future generations

arguments.title: Long-term consequences are partially knowable
arguments.description: If scientific method is valid and prediction/control are possible, then we can make reasonable predictions about long-term consequences of present actions.
arguments.conclusion: Long-term planning based on evidence is possible

arguments.title: Computational theory of mind is correct
arguments.description: If mind-body problem is solvable and artificial consciousness is possible, then mental processes are fundamentally computational in nature.
arguments.conclusion: Minds are essentially information processing systems

arguments.title: Global coordination problems require institutional solutions
arguments.description: If global cooperation is achievable but natural coordination fails, then explicit institutional mechanisms are needed for global challenges.
arguments.conclusion: Global problems need institutional solutions

arguments.title: International cooperation is possible
arguments.description: If global cooperation is achievable and liberal democracy is optimal, then democratic nations can cooperate effectively on global challenges.
arguments.conclusion: Democratic nations can solve global problems together

arguments.title: Biological limitations are surmountable
arguments.description: If human nature is improvable and scientific method is valid, then aging, disease, and death could eventually be overcome through technology.
arguments.conclusion: Technology can overcome biological constraints

arguments.title: The universe lacks inherent purpose
arguments.description: If naturalism is well-supported and scientific method reveals no cosmic teleology, then the universe operates without inherent purpose or meaning.
arguments.conclusion: The universe is purposeless at the cosmic level

arguments.title: Existential authenticity is possible
arguments.description: If choices exist and values guide choices, then individuals can live authentically according to their self-chosen values and commitments.
arguments.conclusion: People can live authentic, self-directed lives

arguments.title: Consciousness has causal powers
arguments.description: If artificial consciousness is possible and mind-body problem is solvable, then conscious states can causally influence physical processes.
arguments.conclusion: Consciousness makes a causal difference in the world

arguments.title: Physical processes are sufficient for consciousness
arguments.description: If computational theory of mind is correct and naturalism is well-supported, then appropriate physical processes are sufficient to generate consciousness.
arguments.conclusion: Consciousness emerges from purely physical processes

edges.explanation: If something exists, logic suggests there's an objective reality
Logic provides the reasoning framework for objective reality
Patterns provide the basis for reliable knowledge
If differences matter, moral distinctions are real
Suffering creates objective moral facts about what matters
Choice is necessary for moral responsibility
Real suffering makes harm prevention important
Consequences mean we can prevent harm
Knowledge and objective reality enable scientific method
Objective reality is what science studies
Moral facts enable genuine moral progress
Causal laws enable prediction and control
Harm prevention is an ethical obligation
Objective stable reality supports metaphysical realism
Stable reality with causal laws suggests natural kinds
Causal laws organize reality into natural kinds
Social contracts require rule of law
Legitimate government requires rule of law
Valid science and realism support naturalism
Moral progress and rationality validate Enlightenment
Technological power must respect human rights
Legitimate government with rule of law supports democracy
Rule of law is essential for constitutional democracy
If something exists, then patterns and regularities can exist within that reality
If logic is reliable, then minds using logic can produce better reasoning
Patterns and regularities in language and meaning enable communication between minds
The ability to reason enables meaningful choices between alternatives
Communication between people enables coordination and cooperation
If actions have consequences, then different actions lead to different outcomes that matter

sources.name: Immanuel Kant
key_works: Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals

sources.name: Empiricism
sources.description: Knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience

sources.name: Rationalism
sources.description: Reason is the primary source of knowledge

sources.name: Utilitarianism
sources.description: Actions are right if they produce the greatest good for the greatest number

sources.name: Deontological Ethics
sources.description: Ethics based on duty and rules rather than consequences

sources.name: Virtue Ethics
sources.description: Ethics based on character traits and virtues

sources.name: Social Contract Theory
sources.description: Political authority derives from agreements among people

sources.name: Natural Law Theory
sources.description: Universal moral principles discoverable by reason

sources.name: Existentialism
sources.description: Existence precedes essence; emphasis on individual experience

sources.name: Philosophical Materialism
sources.description: Reality consists only of matter and energy

sources.name: Philosophical Idealism
sources.description: Reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual
